1.text: Whither is thy beloved gone, O thou fairest among women? Whither hath thy beloved turned him, That we may seek him with thee?’

2.text: My beloved is gone down into his garden, To the beds of spices, To feed in the gardens, And to gather lilies.

3.text: I am my beloved’s, and my beloved is mine, That feedeth among the lilies.’

4.text: Thou art beautiful, O my love, as Tirzah, Comely as Jerusalem, Terrible as an army with banners.

5.text: Turn away thine eyes from me, For they have overcome me. Thy hair is as a flock of goats, That trail down from Gilead.

6.text: Thy teeth are like a flock of ewes, Which are come up from the washing; Whereof all are paired, And none faileth among them.

7.text: Thy temples are like a pomegranate split open Behind thy veil.

8.text: There are threescore queens, And fourscore concubines, And maidens without number.

9.text: My dove, my undefiled, is but one; She is the only one of her mother; She is the choice one of her that bore her. The daughters saw her, and called her happy; Yea, the queens and the concubines, and they praised her.

10.text: Who is she that looketh forth as the dawn, Fair as the moon, Clear as the sun, Terrible as an army with banners?

11.text: I went down into the garden of nuts, To look at the green plants of the valley, To see whether the vine budded, And the pomegranates were in flower.

12.text: Before I was aware, my soul set me Upon the chariots of my princely people.

13.text: Return, return, O Shulammite; Return, return, that we may look upon thee. What will ye see in the Shulammite? As it were a dance of two companies.
